issues.description: PersonService is implemented as instance methods in the template (and described by the problem), but the solution repository replaces/augments them with static methods and an internal singleton. This changes how callers must invoke the API (static vs. instance) and breaks consistency with the dependency-injected usage shown in the rest controller. Concretely, the template PersonService declares public instance methods (savePerson, deletePerson, getAllPersons) while the solution PersonService exposes public static methods and private instance helpers. PersonResource in the solution then inconsistently mixes static and instance calls (e.g. calling PersonService.savePerson(...) statically in createPerson but personService.savePerson(...) on the injected instance in updatePerson/deletePerson). This mismatch is structural: it will confuse students about whether PersonService should be used via DI or via static calls, and the solution-code mixture likely causes compilation errors because some instance methods no longer exist as public members.
issues.suggested_fix: Keep PersonService as a normal Spring @Service with public instance methods (savePerson, deletePerson, getAllPersons) as in the template and call them via the injected personService instance in PersonResource. Remove the static API and singleton instance from PersonService, and make sure PersonResource uses only the injected personService (e.g. personService.savePerson(...), personService.deletePerson(...), personService.getAllPersons(...)). This restores consistency with dependency injection, the problem description, and the template, and prevents compilation/runtime errors.

issues.description: The problem statement and the template expect an instance-based PersonService (the controller/resource should forward calls to the injected personService instance). The template PersonService defines instance methods (savePerson, deletePerson, getAllPersons) and PersonResource declares an injected personService field (but is unimplemented). In the solution, PersonService was changed to expose static wrapper methods (e.g. public static Person savePerson(Person)) and internal instance methods (savePersonInternal, getAllPersonsInternal); PersonResource in the solution calls PersonService.savePerson(...) (a static call) while still declaring an injected personService field. This mixes two different ways of referring to the same conceptual service (instance field personService vs. static class PersonService) and introduces unexpected API shape changes (static wrappers and internal method renames). Students expecting to forward requests to the injected PersonService (as shown in the problem text and mirrored by NoteResource/template patterns) will be confused by the solution's static usage and the internal renames (savePersonInternal, getAllPersonsInternal).
issues.suggested_fix: Restore a consistent API shape across artifacts: make PersonService instance methods (savePerson, deletePerson, getAllPersons) and have PersonResource use the injected personService field (e.g. return ResponseEntity.ok(personService.savePerson(person));). Remove or avoid static wrappers (savePerson/getAllPersons static) and internal renames (savePersonInternal) to match the template and the pattern used for NoteService/NoteResource. This keeps naming and usage consistent with the problem statement and reduces student confusion.
